title: Interface to GESIS Search
text: rgesis provides simple, programmatic reproducible GESIS search engine. allows retrieval metadata records like research datasets, variables, publications, tools. Based , package can also download survey data data archive. Note GESIS search API can accessed directly, need logged download survey data. can create user account . rgesis takes continuous credentials management OAuth authentication using {keyring} {httr2} packages.

title: Download survey data — gesis_data
text: hit Object class gesis_hit returned gesis_search gesis_get dataset ID. dataset ID passed, function performs call gesis_get. download_purpose Purpose use research data demanded GESIS. Must one "final_thesis", "commercial_research", "non_scientific", "further_education", "scientific_research", "studies", "lecturer". path Path downloaded file stored. Defaults temporary file path. type Type data download. Must one "dataset", "questionnaire", "codebook", "otherdocs". Defaults "dataset". list available data types given record can retrieved using gesis_file_types. select Character string select data file case multiple files available selected data type. character string matched file label using regular expressions. argument can also used match explicitly file extensions, e.g. "\\.sav" "\\.dat". list file labels given record can retrieved using gesis_files. NULL, multiple files detected, session interactive, prompts user select file. Defaults NULL. prompt TRUE, allows function open interactive prompt case multiple files found select either NULL fails select file unambiguously. FALSE, throws error case. Defaults TRUE run interactive session.

text: path downloaded file. Depending selected file, different ways read file contents. Traditionally, data files offered Stata SPSS file formats can read using haven package.

title: Download survey data — gesis_data
code: if (FALSE) { # retrieve a search record to pass on to gesis_data() hit <- gesis_search(   "allbus",   publication_year = c(2019, 2020),   type = "research_data" )  # in interactive mode, the function can be run without arguments path <- gesis_data(hit[[1]])  # in other cases, certain arguments should be provided path <- gesis_data(hit[[1]], download_purpose = "non_scientific", select = "\\.sav")  # you can also simply pass a dataset ID path <- gesis_data("ZA3753", select = "\\.por")  # data files must be read using other tools and packages, e.g. haven haven::read_por(path)  # ... or pdftools path <- gesis_data("ZA3753", select = "fb\\.pdf", type = "questionnaire") pdftools::pdf_text(path) }

title: GESIS Search — gesis_search
text: query search term query. Terms can seperated operators / . operator specified, defaults operator specified default_operator. NULL, searches records. Queryless searches can still filtered using parameters . type Type search results retrieve. Can one "research_data", "variables", "instruments_tools", "publication", "gesis_bib", "gesis_web" "gesis_person". NULL, includes result types.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      abstract #> 1                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         Provides an overview of the relationship between climate change and migration. The study brings together both case studies and syntheses from different parts of the world and discusses empirical evidence, methodological challenges, conceptual gaps, policy responses, and normative issues. The book constitutes an introduction to one of the most discussed but least understood consequences of climate change and brings together contributors from a wide range of disciplines, including anthropology, climatology, demography, geography, law, political science and sociology. Tables, Figures. #> 2                         This article situates Japan in the international climate security debate by analysing competing climate change discourses. In 2020, for the first time, the Japanese Ministry of the Environment included the term “climate crisis” (kikō kiki) in its annual white paper, and the Japanese parliament adopted a “climate emergency declaration” (kikō hijō jitai sengen). Does this mean that Japan’s climate discourse is turning toward the securitisation of climate change? Drawing on securitisation theory, this article investigates whether we are seeing the emergence of a climate change securitisation discourse that treats climate change as a security issue rather than a conventional political issue. The analysis focuses on different stakeholders in Japan’s climate policy: the Japanese Ministry of the Environment, the Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the parliament, the Cabinet, and sub- and non-state actors. Through a discourse analysis of ministry white papers and publications by other stakeholders, the article identifies a burgeoning securitisation discourse that challenges, albeit moderately, the status quo of incrementalism and inaction in Japan’s climate policy. This article further highlights Japan’s position in the rapidly evolving global debate on the urgency of climate action and provides explanations for apparent changes and continuities in Japan’s climate change discourse. #> 3 <NA> #> 6  While climate change has become a salient political and social issue in Western societies, we know relatively little about how these societies will react to one of the potentially important consequences of climate change: increasing migration flows. By means of a representative online survey in Germany, this paper therefore investigates for the very first time to what extent citizens in industrialized societies are willing to accept climate change migrants, especially in comparison with other groups of migrants and refugees, and the circumstances and principles under which they would accept them. The findings show that climate change migrants receive high support levels comparable with those enjoyed by political refugees (migrants who need special protection) and that contrast with attitudes towards economic migrants (who are often not seen as in need of special protection). We also see that people are more likely to accept justifications for taking climate change migrants when they realize that the expected number of migrants is relatively low. While arguments about morality, corrective justice, and a country’s capacity lead to similar acceptance rates in general, the latter argument plays a more important role for highly educated people and non-environmentalists than the former two. The findings of this study allow us to better prepare for potential conflicts that might emerge with increasing migration flows caused by climate change. #> 7
